job_title: Coordinator in Tulsa, OK
pros: The Job itself is helpful to the community

review_title: Great Balance, Pay could be much better

review_title: It was interesting working here - much different than OU Norman campus.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: New building, parking garage, near highway
cons: Not many places to eat within walking distance. Crazy traffic on Lincoln.

job_title: Professor in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Excellent faculty, staff and students. Reasonable teaching load. 12-month salary.
cons: Could use more support staff.

job_title: Data Specialist in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Beautiful campus, flowering trees and waterfalls and wishing wells. Supportive work environment. Calm, peaceful, everyone is kind. They trust you to do your job, no micromanagement. Oklahoma Teachers Retirement, 14 paid holidays, and about 24 days of PTO for hourly staff.
cons: I wish the benefits were less expensive and covered more, and I wish public education paid better but I'm happy at work and that matters. Alot.

review_title: Low pay, stress depends on your PI.
job_title: Research Technician in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Depending on your PI, the atmosphere is very laid back. Most of the labs are very flexible with your schedule. 

This is a good job to get some experience in the field and learn the politics of this career. Very diverse group of people leads to some great friends.

The benefits are surprisingly good (health insurance is mostly paid by the University) and they will give you more PTO than you know what to do with.
cons:
Due to it being grant funded research the pay is terrible and there is almost never room for raises. Job security is very much dependent on the PI getting more funding.

The stress level of the job is highly dependent on your PI, they can either be a mentor that tries to foster success or an absolute tyrant that belittles you in front of everyone.

You have to pay for parking on campus even if you're an employee.

Overall I wouldn't recommend this job as a career or any kind of long term prospect. The Primary Investigators expect the technicians to have high turnover, so as such they don't usually treat them with much respect.

If you are going to grad school then yes I would recommend this job.

job_title: HR Trainer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Benefits and time off were great! Supervisor was one of the best I've ever had. Loved my job and teaching other employees skills.
cons: The politics of the university would be challenging especially between faculty and staff. Took a bit of time to get used too.

review_title: Toxic culture with non-existent Human Resources department.
job_title: Sr. Project Manager in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Number of days off and no-cost to employee retirement plan
cons: Too many to list on here. Just Google reviews of this workplace and their financial and human capital performance.

review_title: No accountability, Staff treated poorly, Low pay
job_title: Student Program Coordinator in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The OTRS Retirement Options are better than average. Most people care a lot about the students. Most people are intellectually competent.
cons: There is little to no accountability. Staff are treated poorly and lesser. Faculty egos are high. People with narrow medical degrees think they understand business concepts better than people with business experience and elite business education. Many faculty interview candidates are 'fools gold' candidates in that they look like quality professionals from the outside but there is often times a reason why they couldn't cut it in medicine. The remaining faculty interview candidates are individuals who use the interview opportunity as an opportunity to increase their pay.

review_title: Flexible work environment but culture is toxic
job_title: Coordinator in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The work environment is flexible. You're able to work the hours that work best for you and leave for an appt, daycare, etc. if needed as long as your work is done. The benefits are good.
cons: The pay is low so the overall morale is low. Departments are slow to cooperate with each other and the culture is toxic-lots of gossip, people tend to be negative about their work. There is little to no room to grow in your position, no bonuses, and no raises unless you fight tooth and nail for it, and even then, you're unlikely to get one.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: 1. Close to downton 2. A highly equiped gym
cons: 1. Salary is not increasing as the living expanse

job_title: Asst. Professor in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Lots of new areas of development

review_title: Great Mentors, Department/Univ system could be improved

job_title: Accountant in Oklahoma City, OK

job_title: Manager in Oklahoma City, OK

review_title: Promises in raises are only fulfilled if you know someone.

Our team of Care Managers are amazing! I love all these girls!
cons: You deal with a lot of trauma from our members on state welfare.

review_title: A good employer, but not the most forward thinking.
job_title: Assistant Professor in Oklahoma City, OK

job_title: Research Assistant in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros: You have PTO that you can use how you see fit, it's not divided up into "work" or "vacation" or "sick", it's all the same and you can use it as necessary. You work with people that want the same thing as you, and are willing to help and cover for you if you need it, just as you would for them.
cons:
Micromanaging is increasing at the university, and an ever increasing need for political (and sometimes pointless) training. Training that directly affects your job (research bias, animal handling, awareness of possible plagiarizing, etc) is necessary, but the number of political training (bias, racial diversity, microaggressions, etc) where you are "this" and not only may you not know it, but there's no way to get rid of it is becoming increasingly frustrating.

Workload can increase on a time, and it can lead to burnout rather easily. If you have a full week/month planned out, something can easily come up and throw everything out the window.

job_title: Campus Police Lieutenant in Oklahoma City, OK

review_title: Competitive salaries, great personal time off benefits, lots of opportunities to advance internally
job_title: Administrative Director in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Entry level paid leave (for anything - vacation, illness, personal time, etc) begins pretty immediately - the first or second month of employment.  No waiting period.  Retirement includes employer contributed, plus two optional retirement plans only available to public employees.  Vesting period as low as 3 years and transferable if you leave.  Really great tuition assistance to pursue a degree at any level, with the option of your supervisor giving you some time during normal working hours for classes if your job function allows. Lots of new jobs at the new hospital being constructed.
cons: You're working in the public sector for a state agency, so salary might not be as high as the private sector, but they seem to keep pace with the market overall.  Some positions in research are based on federal or other grants, and may not be permanent, but the university works to try and find you other internal jobs if grants aren't renewed.

job_title: Patient Service Representative IV in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Good benefits, easy schedule, PTO.
cons:
1. No room for growth
2. Low wages
3. Cattiness
4. Favortism

job_title: Patient Account Representative in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great Benefits, give classes to help you grow as an individual and professionaly, free gym and health classes, room to move forward in your career and they are always doing nice fun things for us
cons: Depending on where you work... The parking can be a little bit of a walk  and you have to pay for parking.  Or they offer free shuttles that run every 10 minutes.

review_title: Excellent education, but not a fantastic environment
job_title: Graduate Student in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Faculty, research, and classes are of standard or superior quality.  There are many extracurricular activities available and lots of support for students. And, one of the big advantages are that with the low cost of living of Oklahoma, your stipend goes a lot farther. In addition, the pace of life allows you more time for family.
cons:
My experience with my specific department (Microbiology and Immunology) has been, at minimum, frustrating. While many of the issues have likely been due to some high turnover within the administrative assistants, not a week goes by without a seminar flier not being mailed out or a similar administrative mistake.  
The only other major complaint I have is that the health insurance is only mediocre.

review_title: Great company with an engaged management team including senior leader and CEO.
job_title: Clinic Manager in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The benefits are amazing, best I have seen at any company. The management team within OU Physicians was phenomenal. Goals were patient satisfaction, employee engagement, and providing high quality patient care.
cons: Working with the department of pediatrics and HCA proved to be rather difficult at times. Dealt with a lot of politics between managers in these two entities. Ultimately it became unbearable, and extremely unpleasant. This was just one specific department, however, I've heard of this occurring in other departments as well.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow/Technical Writer and Editor in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Research focused public university. No shortage of research space. Some good core facilities. Campus life tends to be conservative but liberal outlooks are welcomed as well. Generally speaking, the city has a low crime rate.
cons: A little parochial in outlook. Too much emphasis on its football legacy. Political conservatism can seep into academic decisions and didactic standards. Best suited to those who have family anchors in the State and do not place a lot of importance on working elsewhere.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Tulsa, OK
pros: Good Football team. Located in town, decent benefits, Most of the employees are good people but many of the middle management types are entrenched in their positions and are not going to support new ideas
cons: Operates on the okie god'ol'boy system, except does not like male LPNs unless you kiss up to the highers ups. Many of the older DRs refuse to use EMR and expect nurses to decipher scrawls and enter their notes into EMR.. Some doctors file cabinets are huge HIPPA violations just waiting for thousands of $$$$ of fines.

job_title: Lab Manager/Research Scientist In A Pediatric Cancer Lab in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Everybody is friendly and generally happy. i am surounded by a very educated staff and faculty who can give educated opinions which is very helpful to me as a pediatric cancer scientist.
cons: The cons of working at OUHSC is that I had to move to Oklahoma where the weather is terrible and the state's landscape is not scenic. In myfirst year  there were two of the biggest tornadoes ever recorded.  There is also a very large number of earthquakes here. I'm originally from California where I had felt a few earthquakes, but I have felt 10 times the number of earthquakes each year than my entire upbringing in Cal.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: not much, work here if you didn't get job anywhere. Use this experience to move to other cities like Dallas, Chicago, NY/NJ, cities in Bay area
cons: Less pay. Less growth/ low chances for career transition to biopharmaceutical industries.Expensive health care for families. No 401k plan for postdocs. Got the excuse of saying its a relatively in expensive city.

job_title: Police Officer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The benefits are good and comparable to other law enforcement. Children of HSC employees receive free tuition to OU. Paid time off is generous and health insurance has low deductibles.  The police department is open to the community and has made positive changes internally over the years to police in modern times.
cons: The biggest problem or issue is the unfair pay. OUHSC officers make significantly less in salary compared to the Norman Campus. HSC officers work in more dangerous situations daily but are not paid accordingly. Head administration makes six figures while others have gone multiple years without even a cost of living increase. This causes high turnover once people realize their is no real growth after the first year. Officers leave this department in droves resulting in the loss of some excellent experienced officers. This has been a stepping stone department and trains some great people that end up leaving for more financial opportunities. This university should allign pay across campuses and also pay in the same range as OKC and Norman Police Departments. The constant turnover and low morale is a result primarily of the lower salary.  OUHSC officers have been treated second class and hopefully the new president will bring this department up to speed with salary and technology.  Officers at OUHSC do not have the basic technology to do their jobs such as MDT's (in car computers). In the 21st century this is required technology and it makes the officers and dispatchers jobs more difficult by not providing this equipment. Norman Campus has all the new equipment including in car computers even though OUHSC Campus is in a high crime area. Please take care of your officers at OUHSC, they deserve to be treated fairly and on par with main campus.

job_title: Patient Service Representative II in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: 18 hours of PTO a month, electronic health records, big campus, good health benefits/options, great training & development team. Good company culture. Clinics are 8-5 M-F. Good entry level job.
cons: No consistency between clinics. They all have different budgets and different responsibilities for the same job role. There is hardly any room for advancement and pay is low. Raises are a joke. Have to pay for parking that is uncovered.

job_title: Patient Service Representative III in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: They will pay for your child's undergraduate degree. You have to pay for your supplies though. Lots of PTO and paid holidays.
cons: You are a state employee, so the raises are non existent.  Boss completely ignores the question when asked for a raise. Oh and make sure you pay your state tax on time because if you don't they can put a lien on your home because you are a state employee.

job_title: Research Assistant in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Generally a good place to work but at the time I was there the government funding of grants was becoming untenable and research was slowing down to the point there was no work to do.  The best thing I can say about OUHSC is that the people you work with are very supportive.
cons: Oftentimes due to budget and or grant constraints you can become stuck in one position and not have any or many opportunities to advance.

review_title: The best place to work if you like the healthcare field.
job_title: Patient Account Representative in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Overall great benefits when it comes to PTO, insurance and 401K. My particular department allows me to choose my hours and work from home for OT. There's a lot of room to move around if you get bored without leaving an employer.
cons: Depends on where you work on campus, department and management.

review_title: Fun place with some big place issues

cons: Pay is adequate, but not as much as you'd make in the private sector. Still, plenty of vacay time.

cons: Understaffed, overworked, multiple EMRs, minimal to no resident benefits

job_title: Research Technician in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: I was given the opportunity to learn a myriad of skills. I was exposed to a lot of different situations, and I had to think out of the box a lot.
cons: Sometimes instructions weren't clear, and it was difficult to get in touch with the PI. It's a very busy place, so it's understandable.

job_title: Mail Carrier in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The benefits are good. And it's very laid back. You will get plenty cardio! If you are a good hard working person, you should have no problem.
cons: No room for advancing. This job would be great for someone that just wants to take advantage of the benefits at an older age.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Academic work like balance always good.
Good quality students in the MHA program.
Many opportunities to work with the local community.
cons: Crazy ego-tripping dean appointing non-tenured faculty as department heads that don't understand research. Have a very strange "I say jump, you say "how high"" mentality for an academic job.

review_title: Good place to work but not well funded
job_title: Research Assistant in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Good salary and nice environment. Not stressful in general.
cons: hard to get a grant or be funded, makes it difficult to perform research. Most PIs do not seek collaborations outside the University of Oklahoma.

job_title: Medical Biller in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great training.  Enjoyed helping patients and working with Nurses and Physicians.  Pay is competitive.
cons: Getting paid once a month.  Parking.  The only two things that would keep me from  re applying to work there.

review_title: Professional for research, great life-work balance.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great scientists in glycobiology area. Great amount of research fundings. ORMF is considered as a very strong research center in south west.
cons: Oklahoma city is too quiet place if you are a person likes dynamic life.

job_title: Social Worker Case Manager in Tulsa, OK
pros: Friendly environment and good people to work with. Patient are wonderful and supportive. A needy area this requires a ton of assistance.
cons: Resources are limited in area. Poverty hinders pt treatment and often contributes to pts not following doctors orders

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Excellent management. Quality was appreciated vs simply filling a role with someone who can perform the tasks. Great benefits and genuine concern for staff and patients.
cons: lower than average pay due to being a university hospital, but great learning experiences

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Good benefits, especially the amount of PTO. Nice to work at an institution that makes a difference ( teaching students in healthcare and treating patients).
cons: Dealing with the uncertainty of the State's finances and budget.

job_title: Fitness Specialist in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Multi faceted job that is active and changing everyday.
cons: Tend to be over used because of the ability to deal with most any situation.

job_title: Research Assistant in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Friendly atmosphere in the department of Microbiology and Immunology.
Cooperation between labs
Convenient location
Good parking options
Very nice health club which is free for students
cons: Fewer options for graduate students than what would be ideal.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Good benefits, lots of PTO, wellness program.....     ..... .   . .

review_title: Challenging  in a good way and wonderful workplace

review_title: Great staff but lacking in professional management

cons: Management in my department was mostly unprofessional and relied on favoritism for any kind advancement.

review_title: Great Place to Work Long Term
job_title: Human Resources Trainer in Oklahoma City, OK

review_title: great place to work and only academic center in region

job_title: IT Architect in Oklahoma City, OK

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Oklahoma City, OK

job_title: Accounting Clerk in Oklahoma City, OK
